qas.question: Which animal was accidentally introduced into Guam?
What was accidentally introduced into Guam?
With the introduction of a non native snake in the area of Guam what impact did it have the island?

answers.text: nearly eliminated the native bird population

qas.question: What has the U.S Department of Agriculture done to help watch for the snakes?

answers.text: has trained detector dogs to keep the snakes out of the island's cargo flow

qas.question: How many native species of birds did Guam have prior to World War II?
How many native species of birds did the Solomon Islands have prior to World War II?
What do Australian authorities do to not send brown tree snakes to Guam accidentally?
What is one of the snakes that is very poisonous to humans?
Where was the U.S. military transport ultimately headed when it accidentally introduced the brown tree snake to Guam?

context: Believed to be a stowaway on a U.S. military transport near the end of World War II, the <a0_0><a1_0><b7_0>brown tree snake<b7_0/><a1_0/><a0_0/> (Boiga irregularis) was accidentally introduced to Guam, that previously had <b4_0><b5_0>no native species<b5_0/><b4_0/> of snake. It <a2_0>nearly eliminated the native bird population<a2_0/>. The problem was exacerbated because the reptile has no natural predators on the island. The brown tree snake, known locally as the kulebla, is native to northern and eastern coasts of Australia, Papua New Guinea, and <b8_0>the Solomon Islands<b8_0/>. While slightly venomous, the snake is relatively harmless to human beings. Although some studies have suggested a high density of these serpents on Guam, residents rarely see the nocturnal creatures. The United States Department of Agriculture <a3_0>has <b6_0>trained detector dogs<b6_0/> to keep the snakes out of the island's cargo flow<a3_0/>. The United States Geological Survey also has dogs capable of detecting snakes in forested environments around the region's islands.
